abstract: Bear Stearns shareholders are understandably furious about the investment bank’s sale to JPMorgan Chase for about $2 a share. Now one of the largest of them is warning that he intends to try and stop it.
lead_paragraph: Bear Stearns shareholders are understandably furious about the investment bank’s sale to JPMorgan Chase for about $2 a share. Now one of the largest of them is warning that he intends to try and stop it.

headline.main: Unhappy Billionaire Prepares to Act on Bear Deal

abstract: James Dimon, the chairman and chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, attempted to win over executives at Bear Stearns who have vowed to fight his offer.
snippet: James Dimon, the chairman and chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, attempted to win over executives at Bear Stearns who have vowed to fight his offer.
lead_paragraph: James Dimon tramped through the rain on Wednesday evening and strode into the headquarters of Bear Stearns, the embattled investment bank he hopes to buy for a mere $2 a share.

headline.main: At Bear Stearns, Meet the New Boss
headline.print_headline: At Bear Stearns, Meet the New Boss

byline.original: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Eric Dash

abstract: The audacious government-orchestrated purchase of Bear Stearns by JPMorgan Chase has dominated headlines and chatter this week. To say there are a plethora of angles to cover — the $2-a-share price, the role of the government, the challenges in closing the deal — is an understatement.
lead_paragraph: The audacious government-orchestrated purchase of Bear Stearns by JPMorgan Chase has dominated headlines and chatter this week. To say there are a plethora of angles to cover — the $2-a-share price, the role of the government, the challenges in closing the deal — is an understatement.

abstract: Borders Group, the struggling bookstore chain, said Thursday it hired JPMorgan and Merrill Lynch to explore strategic alternatives, including a sale of all or part of the company. Shares of Borders initially rose in Friday trading but soon moved sharply lower.
lead_paragraph: Borders Group, the struggling bookstore chain, said Thursday it hired JPMorgan and Merrill Lynch to explore strategic alternatives, including a sale of all or part of the company. Shares of Borders initially rose in Friday trading but soon moved sharply lower.
